I’m Patrick. Professionally, I'm a technologist focused on how design and tech come together to make great products. Personally, I'm a creative person that rarely goes a day without making something. I’m also apparently very pensive when I drink my coffee.

I am not your typical developer. Yes, I can write production ready front-end code, but I thrive on working throughout the full human-centered design process. I started my career as a brand strategist at the global ad agency Leo Burnett, sythesizing myriad research into winning strategies for Fortune 500 companies. I then worked as a front-end developer on a highly collaborative product design team at American Express where I did everything from competitive audits, to field research, to user testing, to rapid prototyping, to building a responsive design system to work across three brands on our prepaid debit platform.

I'm currently working for Vroozi, a fintech startup in Los Angeles, where I'm helping to refine a business puchasing platform that processed over a billion dollars of spend last year.

Vroozi

UI Developer

I moved to Los Angeles in June 2016 to start a new adventure after spending a few years in New York. I linked up with LA native, fintech startup Vroozi (based in Sherman Oaks), to help continue their product development and in particular to continue to drive their push toward 100% mobile enabled business purchasing and expense management.

Responsive UI + Emails

Vroozi is focused on delivering a mobile friendly procurement platform, but it wasn't initially built that way. I'm working on transitioning the product to a truly mobile first approach for design and development.

UI Code Guidelines

Vroozi uses a lot of contract developers all over the world, but doesn't have a clear code style guide for those developers to follow. I'm helping to develop those guidelines while also reviewing and managing all the pull requests for new work going into the platform.

Component Architecture

Vroozi is built with Angular and we have been gradually adopting the ES6 component pattern within the framework for many new UI features. I'm working on figuring out the best way to also develop modular styles to support the component based system.

American Express

Front End Development + UX Design

My corner of the Amex universe revolved around the prepaid debit card platform, Serve. My team was responsible for the logged-in web experience of three brands on this platform: Amex Serve, Walmart Bluebird and Target Redcard. These three products are full-featured banking alternatives similar to the account you might have with a traditional bank like Chase or Wells Fargo (including bill pay, direct deposit, savings etc...). Check out the links below where I go into more detail on my tech skill set as well as highlight a few key findings from three projects.

Want a demo and code samples? I have them ready. Just ask and I'll give you a link to download them.

Tech Stack

What I've used and hope to use

Every company has unique front-end development needs and philosophies, so let me break down what I've worked with at Amex and what I hope to do in my next role.

Serve Responsive Web

HTML, SCSS, Compass, JS, Jekyll

To better serve our largely mobile user base, we redesigned the logged-in experience to be 100% responsive and optimized for simple use across all key devices.

Amex Offers

JS, jQuery, Dust.js, API Integration

By pairing data from an existing API with new user insights, we refreshed an established American Express perk for our unique set of cardholders.

Walmart Cash Pickup

Service Journey, Logic Map, User Testing

Amex partnered with Walmart and Ria Money Transfer to deliver a streamlined cash pickup and transfer experience for Bluebird and Serve customers.

General Assembly

Web Development Immersive Student

After two years as a strategist, I realized I wasn't happy just selling a product; I wanted to build one. Learning to code became my path to having a seat at the product development table. So I quit my job, moved to NYC and put myself through the grind at General Assembly before finding my niche at Amex.

Please note: These are projects from my earliest days as a developer. They're fun to browse, but I've obviously learned a lot in the years since making them.

Echonest App

Musician "hotness" + popularity ranking

I'm a big music fan, so for my final project at GA I developed a simple ranking app based on data from the Echonest, a super in-depth API that now powers a lot of Spotify's features.

Live From New York

NY Times Archive Search App

My very first web app makes simple queries to the NY Times archives API. Search for your birthday! You're bound to find something interesting. Is this a great feat of engineering or design? Not by a long shot. But it's always fun to remember the humble beginnings.

Leo Burnett

Junior Brand Strategist

I started my career as a brand strategist at one of the biggest ad agencies in the world. I translated all kinds of consumer research into communications and designs for Fortune 500 companies like Esurance, Sprint and MillerCoors. I learned a ton at Burnett: from managing the client/agency relationship to leading stakeholder interviews to developing a winning challenger strategy for a major brand. I also started learning to code on weeknights and weekends before making a leap of faith to become a professional developer.

Patrick Holiday

My songwriting and music production side hustle

Yeah, I use a pseudonym. It's a nod to my little hometown of Hollidaysburg, Pennsylvania. I've been involved with music for as long as I can remember. First came the piano lessons, then the years of choir, acappella groups and musicals and now I've honed in on music production and songwriting. So if you wanna chat about effect chains in Ableton Live, the lyric structure of that pop song you can't get out of your head or even if you just wanna have a good old fashioned jam session, I'm your man.

"Let Me Feel It" is about that moment in a relationship where you have to let it all out to reach the next level of connection.

"Crush" is about those tough "Define the Relationship" talks when you're not on the same page with your significant other.

"At Least We Have Tonight" is a bittersweet song about a one night stand and missed chances.

Heyo. Thanks again for checking out my work.

I'm Los Angeles based, Pennsylvania-born, and always down to chat over a coffee or beer.
